It’s interesting to me — and a little sad — that every time the gun debate comes up on Twitter, my inbox and mentions are full of anger, cussing, insults, etc. 

We don’t have to agree on every issue (or any issue, honestly) to be civil. We all want the same result.

We grieve for the Americans murdered in Pittsburgh. All of us have to fight the rise of anti-Semitism and hateful rhetoric against those who look, love, or pray differently. And we have to stop making it so easy for those who want to harm the innocent to get their hands on a gun.
In retrospect Sandy Hook marked the end of the US gun control debate. Once America decided killing children was bearable, it was over.

My heart is with Pittsburgh today, including the law enforcement officers who responded to today’s shooting.

Houses of worship should be places of community, faith, and family. We MUST find common-sense solutions to end gun violence and ensure our right to safe communities.

Trump said that what happened at the synagogue would have been prevented by an armed guard on site. And yet the gunman shot three armed police officers.

Let’s stop with the good-guy-with-a-gun fantasy. Let’s start with getting AR-15s off the market.

We grieve for the Americans murdered in Pittsburgh. All of us have to fight the rise of anti-Semitism and hateful rhetoric against those who look, love, or pray differently. And we have to stop making it so easy for those who want to harm the innocent to get their hands on a gun.
We stand with the people of Pittsburgh and the members of the Tree of Life Synagogue, and stand against hate, anti-Semitism, and senseless gun violence.  We must not tolerate this.
Jon Snow asks Pittsburgh's mayor whether it's "time for the political classes to get together and talk about getting the gun out of American society." https://t.co/cdyCzNpuA9
